required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Bovine Colostrum/ Egg Supplementation in Young Malawian Children
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Bovine Colostrum/ Egg Supplementation in Young Malawian Children

collaborator.agency: University of Malawi College of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The trial will consist of adding either a supplement of 4.3g egg powder + 5.7g bovine colostrum or a control flour along with a multiple micronutrient powder to the diets of healthy Malawian children 9 months of age. This supplement provides additional essential amino acids, choline and immunoactive colostrum. Children will be receive either the supplement or control for 12 weeks. Children will have regular follow-up where anthropometry is measured. At enrollment and after 12 weeks, stool will be collected and a urinary lactulose permeability test conducted. Children will be measured at enrollment and at weeks 2, 4, 8, 12, 20, 32 after enrollment.

primary_outcome.description: The lactulose permeability test involves drinking 20 mL of a sugar water solution and collecting urine for 4 hours thereafter
Change in length expressed as anthropometric z-score from enrollment to end point

secondary_outcome.description: Caregiver report of number of days they child has diarrhea over the course of the study

secondary_outcome.measure: Adverse effects of the bovine colostrum/ egg
secondary_outcome.description: Caregiver report of number of days they child has adverse effects over the course of the study
Looking at the 16S configuration in stool samples collected

arm_group.description: 4.3 grams egg powder + 5.7 grams bovine colostrum

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy Children at 9-10 months of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Malnutrition
- congenital abnormalities
- chronic diseases such as heart disease, cerebral palsy, or HIV infection
